div.p: Greetings. Reverend Father in Christ, yesterday I wrote to you about the affairs of the Rhaetians.
This evening I was invited to dinner by the lord's legate.
Letters arrived, brought by the courier of the city of Zurich.
What was in them, I do not know, except that the lord seemed somewhat sad after reading them. What he mentioned at the table were these:
The lord of Angusola is lingering in Urania and spreading his poison there. It is certain that the efforts of the Spaniards are not insignificant.
Those who were sent to us have not yet proposed anything; what they seek is not unclear.

Tomorrow or the day after, there will be a smaller assembly (bytag) here in the name of the French. For he had summoned our people before he was aware of the arrival of the Spaniards. - I am sending my writing on the plague, which you will read either alone or with a few others, so that he has nothing to complain about. You will return it sometime, but only through trusted people; I do not want it to spread, as he takes it so badly.
You will say it is quite sharp; but you must consider that the pain I conceived from your illness forced this out.
I can present much more absurd things, and those good men defend all of this. They say they do not approve of the cruelty; but they approve of the cause.

Furthermore, I can affirm that I was greatly offended by the speech of the one who debated with me; everything was so pagan, not a word about divine providence. But, as I wrote yesterday, let everything be silenced and buried by me.
Therefore, I want you to read this with a few others, for whom it was written. I am also sending the royal edict, which I wish to be returned to Mr. Gesner.
Yesterday I wrote to the same, now at least I return this writing with thanks. I am not sure about the departure of the courier; therefore, I wrote this at night.
It may happen that he stays here tomorrow and in the meantime, if there is anything new worthy of your knowledge, I will learn more. Farewell, reverend Father in Christ.
Chur, 28th of November, in the year 1564.
If it seems appropriate to you, also let my father-in-law read it, but in such a way that only one reads it.
To the most esteemed Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, his lord and much-revered father in Christ.
